definition: Deductible is the amount you pay out of pocket each year before the insurer starts sharing costs. A higher deductible usually lowers premium but increases your cost when you claim.
Premium is what you pay the insurer to keep the policy active. It is paid regardless of whether you make a claim.
Coinsurance is the percentage of covered costs you pay after meeting the deductible. For example, 20% coinsurance means you pay 20% and the insurer pays 80% of covered expenses.
Out-of-pocket maximum (OOP max) is the most you could pay in a year for covered services. After you reach it, the insurer pays 100% of covered costs for the rest of the year.
Coverage limit is the maximum the insurer will pay for certain services or the policy overall. Higher limits reduce the chance you exhaust coverage during major events.
Annual benefit maximum is the total the plan will pay in a policy year across covered services.
Network size indicates how many hospitals/clinics are in-network. Using in-network providers keeps costs predictable and lower.
A family floater covers the whole family under a single sum insured. It is often cheaper than four individual policies but the sum insured is shared.
Waiting period is the time after purchase before certain benefits (e.g., pre-existing) become payable.
